question_title: RAID Arrays...? [SEP] question_content: Ive got 3 disks 1 SATA, 2 IDE, 2 of them are 80 GB, one of the IDE's are 250. On the 250 GB IDE drive I have Data. I dont want to lost the data since I am adding an SATA to my computer for the first time. Will I lose that data if I am doing RAID O striping for performance? Im not doing RAID 1 which is Mirroring for Security. I already started the process but have not rebooted. Im scared it will reformat. What is going to happen..?? [SEP] best_answer: The best advice I can give you (which may be too late, if I understand things right) is to back up the data you want to preserve, off the computer, so that if something goes wrong with the RAID configuration, you will be able to cope with the loss. Depending on how your RAID setup is designed, you may (or may not) be able to use IDE drives and SATA drives in the same RAID setup. They have very different latencies adn other characteristics, which may confuse the RAID software/firmware, and perhaps the operating system too. 

Anyway, a few DVDs will probably be enough, at least for a temporary backup. DVDs and CDs aren't so sturdy and suited for long term storage as many think. Any damage to the edges of the disk or the label side of the one sided sort, is quite likely to start a corroson process which will lose data. Protection of the data storage layer is only a thickness of lacquer there. The sturdiest side of these things is the reading side, as it has a somewhat thick (a few millimeters, anyway) layer of plastic between the outside world and the data storage mechanism. But they can probably be safeguarded long enough to be useful in this case. 

If possible, I'd suggest RAID 5 as it allows you (in the best case) to survive the complete loss of a disk, rebuilding the data on it from the remaining data. Whether that will be possible for your hardwae (and operating system) is another thing, of course. But a full implementation will require more disks than you have; there's a way to do RAID 5 with only three disks, if I recall correctly, but I'd spend a little on the hardware to reduce implementational complications. A test run is, I think, a good thing. Record some test data on your RAID 5 setup, then remove one disk entirely, and see if the data can be successfuly restored. Don't count on it all working until you've had a successful test...

Best of luck, whatever you decide to do.

question_title: My computer won't urn cds and I've burend cds before please help me? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: The error with the burned CDs could really be a number of things.  It could be that there's a malfunction with the CD itself, in which case, I'd try bruning with another CD (if you haven't already tried that).  It could be that there's a problem with your hardware...The lens is dirty or scratched, a mechanism has burned out, and electrical circuit is on the fritz.  Listen to the sounds that your computer makes when you insert a CD.  Is the disc even spinning up when its inserted, or is the computer not even recognizing the disc?  If that's the case, you'll need to install a new CD drive.  The other issue that could be a factor is software trouble.  It could be that your CD burning software is missing a driver or has been affected with a virus.  \n\nI'd recommend you start with a new blank CD, if you haven't already.  If that's not the issue, go with the software cause..  reinstall the program that you're using to burn.  Make sure that all the necessary drivers and product key is on-hand for the installation.  If it appears that software is not an issue, and your drive has gone bad, you'll need to replace that.  Hope this helps.

question_title: ok i have a comp that i cant start up windows it says stop error i cant get to nothing to fix anything? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: Shut it completely off and unplug it from the wall.  Open the case so you can see the motherboard.  Look for a silver battery on the motherboard (about 1 inch diameter or smaller).  Somewhere close to the battery, you will see a jumper (also known as a link setting).  

This is the CMOS jumper, and it will be positioned on 2 of the 3 available pins.  Remove it from the the 2 pins on one side (could be on pins 1 and 2 or on 3 and 4...doesn't matter) and place it on the other end (pin 2 will be used on both settings, only 1 and 3 will change).  Let it sit for 10 seconds, then return it to the position it was in when you found it.

Replace the cover and plug it back into the wall.  Turn on the computer and let it try to boot up.  If it works, cool, you've fixed it.  If you get the same error, you need to reboot and this time when it starts up press whatever key you need to get into the Bios (could be delete or F8 or F12, whatever).

Once in the Bios, make it search for you fixed disk drives...it should come up with each drive and how big they are.  If it finds all the installed drives, great!  Hit Save And Exit and allow it to reboot.  If it still comes up with that error, you may have a corrupted drive...it's now time to call in the professionals.

I hope this helps!

question_title: who hosts the internet? [SEP] question_content: what i mean is there has to be a computer or server somewhere that connects the 'internet' to everyone? [SEP] best_answer: My god, I am trying to think of a way to explain it, there are a million links if you search, but think of a million large spider webs hooked together, you do have one (Company) thats does take care of all the names, somebody has to so there would only be only one of each name, You have millions of web servers, that are computers that can have 1 to 50,000 sites on each one.
If you use  your telephone line and modem or high speed connection, the computer connects to the ISP's server. Once there, the ISP acts as a gateway connecting you to any computer hooked to the World Wide Web, using browsers like Internet Explorer or Netscape. 

Next, you type in a URL (Uniform Resource Locator) - such as www.yahoo.com. The computer translates this into a number - the IP address - that is unique to every web page and computer, making it possible for machines to recognise each other. The machines then 'talk' to each other using 'languages' called protocols. Specifically, the protocol in question is TCP/IP, which allows computers to describe data to one another over a network. 

Every computer on the WWW understands these two protocols, and can therefore communicate amicably. TCP/IP is actually two different things. TCP (Transmission Control Protocol) takes the information you want to send over the Internet, and breaks it into small chunks of data called 'packets' that can include programming, text, pictures, sound or video in various combinations. IP (Internet Protocol) takes over and routes those packets through computers to get them to their destination. 

When the packets arrive at the destination computer, TCP reassembles them into what you finally see as a web page on your computer screen. TCP/IP is further broken down into specialised protocols like STMP (which works with email), Ftp (for simple file transfers) and the omnipresent 'http://' (Hypertext Transfer Protocol), which is how Web browsers work. 

Sounds a bit intimidating? Just remember: you have gone through each of these steps every time you have logged on to the Internet! .

question_title: application of artificial intelligence in medical laboratory science diagnosis?. what is process control syste [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: Well, using neural networks, the program can be trained to predict certain outcomes.

Say you have a bunch of random data (the more random the better) that you think could build a connection to a specified outcome.  You can feed this data through neural network where it'll learn the data and any trends throughout.  Then you can program it to give certain results.

Another example:

Your an ad agency and you want to target only four types of people.  Well obviously there are more than four categories of people to target, but with neural networks you can come up with four pretty good ads that'll cover all the people.  So you take data of people at Central Park.  You notice that people who wear white shirts usually eat hot dogs on friday, but only if the temperature is above 70 F.  So now you have for data points: color of shirt, what the eat, when they eat it, and on what kind of day.  Now do this same thing for 100's or 1000's of people and feed that data into the neural network you program.  The program if trained enough can come up with some conclusions about what those people would like for our advertisement.

This is a very simplified analysis but you can kind of get the point:

Look at someones heredity, sertain genomes, and train the neural network with that data and then possibly figure out some pretty neat conclusions from that.

question_title: What is ID3 tags? How does it show MP3 files's information? [SEP] question_content: Do me a favor of responding me as soon as possible because It's as the matter of fact urgent and itchy to have an overview. Pleeaasse! Thank you, those who is responsible for this. [SEP] best_answer: MP3 files and many other formats where designed not only to store the audio information, but a lot of other things.

Think that MP3 as a box for many things, for short the information about what it contains (ID3 tags) and the audio information. If you can see inside the file will look something like:

BEGIN_OF_CONTENT
   ID3_TAG_V1.0
      Artist: Anyone
      Song: Whatever
   END_OF_ID3_TAG_V1.0
   ID3_TAG_V2.0
      Artist: Anyone
      Song: Whatever
      More stuff: Here I am.
   END_OF_ID3_TAG_V2.0
   BEGIN_OF_AUDIO_CONTENT
      Here comes the song
   END_OF_AUDIO_CONTENT
END_OF_CONTENT

As you can see the file could even has more than 1 TAG, the ID3 is just one of many and it (by now) has two version (V1 and V2).

Hope this helps you.

question_title: How Do I Print Something Out in Landscape form?? [SEP] question_content: I HAVE MICROSOFT OFFICE 2003 AND I'M USING MICROSOFT WORD BUT I DON'T KNOW HOW YO PRINT SOMETHING OUT IN LANDSCAPE FORM!! SOMEONE PLZ TELL ME HOW!! [SEP] best_answer: To print a Doc in Landscape you have to tell the program to do it. Oh! you want to know how.
When you are ready to print. DO NOT hit the Print button at the top of the screen. Instead click the FILE button in the top left corner of the screen, select the "Page Setup" buttom and you should see the buttons "Portrait and Landscape." Click the "Landscape button", then click the "Print Preview button" just as a check to insure you are now in "Landscape" mode.
Another way is to select "Landscape" before you start writing your doc, that way you create your doc in that mode. Again, do a print preview before printing just to make sure.
Ivan

question_title: I have a NEW computer, do I really need to "close other applications during installation??"? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: Depends on what you are installing. The reason that installing applications tell you to close all other applications is that if other applications are using system files that the installing application needs to update, it will not be able to update them since they will be in use. So if you are not exactly sure what system drivers that those applications are installing, I would recommend closing all open applications with the exception of anti-virus and spyware programs.

question_title: IT dependency on critical applications in the retail industry how they can achieve the applications robust? [SEP] question_content: With the increased dependency on critical applications in It what we can believe any retail organization should be looking at to ensure that the  IT (Information Technology) applications are
-robust
-supportable
-scalable and secure [SEP] best_answer: A robust application is one that continues to operate correctly even under stress placed by environmental factors.

In the retail industry such factors that place stress on a program are,

1.  Inexperience in operation brought about by unskilled and semi skilled workers using it.
2.  Environmental factors such as recovery from power fluctuations.
3.  Destructive behaviour applied to it from such factors as sabotage by an individual and the threat of virus activity in communications.

To achieve robust operation generally is a three part strategy. The first is thorough implementation of exception handling within the software and recovery to exception. The second is adequate research at the design analysis stage to account for faults and recovery. Finally the third part is to implement the software with a carefully supervised alpha and beta implementation to oversea the program for shortcomings or unexpected problems. 


The criteria for robust operation might be to access such factors above against loss of income to the retailer.

question_title: I have had access to www.ezboard.com for years.  Suddenly 2 weeks ago, I only get "unavailable? any ideas? [SEP] question_content: I am on an wireless intranet with wireless access IP.  All computers on the intranet have different versions of Windows (98, ME, XP) and problem exists on all computers. ISP has no ideas.  Anyone here have any idea what is going on? [SEP] best_answer: Hi probalby no help but I can get to www.ezboard.com fine. I would suggest maybe a few things that are pretty basic and you may have already tried. First do you use a proxy to access the internet. From Internet Explorer go Tools, Internet Options, then on the connection tabs then look at the LAN settings (if you are on Wirless DSL). If there is anything in there then your computer is going through a proxy before reaching the internet. The issue could be caused by that.

Alternatively sometimes ISP's will block an IP range if they suddenly get loads of spam, but it can be a nightmare trying to talk to someone from most ISP's that will look into it.

Two other things you can do... if you can get to your command prompt (Dos Prompt) normally under start menu, accesories.

Type ping www.ezboard.com 
it will then try to send packets to the server - if this works and comes back with response times it may not be your ISP after all but something in your browser.

When you ping it it will say something like pinging www.ezboard.com (nnn.nnn.nnn.nnn) where the number in the brackets is the IP address of the server.

If that works try typin tracert nnn.nnn.nnn.nnn where nnn is the number in brackets from your ping. This will then show all the steps the packet is taking. Interstingly when I tried this it kept failing at a 64.125.nnn.nnn - it kept going around in circles before timing out.

Anysort of information like this is useful to give to your ISP.

question_title: what do i need for wires for a internal dvd burner, and what type is recommendedfor a emachines computer? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: Does your computer have a free 5.25" external bay?  If so, open the computer and take a look at the ribbon(cable) attached to your cd-rom.  If you see a connector in the middle of the ribbon you only have to attach that (and a power connector) to the dvd-burner.  The original drive will need jumper settings of master and the new burner should be set as slave.  Power connectors are plastic with 4 holes.  I would suggest you buy a retail version instead of OEM.  OEM lacks software.  If your original ide ribbon only has one connector you can easily purchase the right type.  They are listed as 3 connectors(mobo and both drives).

I would suggest Newegg also.  They have many for around $40.
I personally have purchased 3 NEC 16x dual-format drives and they work excellently.

http://www.newegg.com/Product/ProductList.asp?Order=PRICE&Page=1&N=2010100005+1036506653&Submit=ENE&SubCategory=5

It looks like the Lite-On oem drives come with software.

Hope this helps.

question_title: iTunes Library taking up all my hard drive?!? [SEP] question_content: My computer has really slowed down since I've been using iTunes... makes sense as I'm using up about 40GB in songs. How can I (a novice computer user) speed my system up again? Do I need to load another hard drive (if I have a slot available)? THANKS! [SEP] best_answer: I have about 10,000 songs in itunes, and my computer is not any slower because of it. You are just storing the files on your disk. This does not use any of the processor unless you are actually accessing the file.

So - the real question is why your computer is slowing.

1/ Over time, you need to defrag your hard drive. Open my computer, right click on your c drive > properties > tools > defragment now. Do this every couple of months.

2/ You have a lot of programs that have snuck into your computer at startup time. install winpatrol (free - use the link below). Check the 'startup programs' tab. if you have more than about 20 items, invistigate each item and disable anything you dont need. Liutilities.com is a great source for this.

3/ If your antivirus is norton or mcaffee, dump them, as they are resource hogs. Just make sure you follow all the remove instructions to get everything out. Install Avast instead. Its free, small, fast, and more effective than the previously mentioned.

4/ lastly, you can blame microsoft's patches every month to a small degree. Every patch they make adds a little bit to the overhead. Its the price we all have to pay for the innocent and not-so-innocent hackers.

Taking care of the 1st three should speed you up considerably. regarding #4, and just overall performance, RAM is the best thing you can buy next to bandwidth. Forget all the accelerators you may hear about. Its just junk.

question_title: is ice  a  mineral?.....glacial    oxide  of   hydrogen? [SEP] question_content: from a n old  prospecter [SEP] best_answer: Yes, if it forms naturally it is a mineral. The name is just ice. There isn't any 'glacial' part, although that does add to the description. Liquid water is NOT a mineral because it is liquid, and man-made ice is not a mineral because it is man-made. It is hydrogen oxide. 

Here's a good definition of a mineral: (I quote)
"To be classified as a "true" mineral, a substance must be a solid and have a crystal structure. It must also be an inorganic, naturally-occurring, homogeneous substance with a defined chemical composition."

Ice is solid. It has a crystal structure. It is inorganic. It is naturally-occurring, and it is only made of one thing, H20, so it fits the definition well.

question_title: Jame wil try out for basketball....? [SEP] question_content: jamie will definietly try out for either basketball or baseball, but not both.  The probability that Jamie will try out for baseball and try out for catcher is 42%.  What is the probability that Jamie wil try out for basketball????

A. 40%
B. 60%
C. 80%
D. 90% [SEP] best_answer: P(A or B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A and B)

P(A) = probability of trying out for basketball
P(B) = probability of trying out for baseball

Now, P (A and B) = 0, since Jamie will not try out for basketball and baseball

P(A or B) = 1 (or 100%), since Jamie will definitely try out for basketball or baseball

So, P(A) + P(B) = 100%
P(B) is more than 42% or more (since you have to consider that Jamie will try out for other positions for baseball).

100% - 42% = 58%
P(A) has to be 58% or lesser. The only answer that is less than 58% is option A (40)

question_title: why does the shower curtain blow inward when the water is running? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: Once I heard about a very serious physics study on that /   I'll try to find it for ya.\n\nHERE IT IS> When the simulation was complete, it showed that the spray drove a vortex. The center of this vortex—much like the center of a cyclone—is a low-pressure region. This low-pressure region is what pulls the shower curtain in. The vortex rotates around an axis that is perpendicular to the shower curtain. It is a bit like a sideways dust devil. But unlike a dust devil, this vortex doesn't die out because it is driven continuously by the shower.

question_title: A stone is thrown horizontally from a vertical cliff 25m high and lands on the ground below, 22m from the . .? [SEP] question_content: foot of the cliff. What was the original horizontal speed of the stone? [SEP] best_answer: Let Time of fall be  t then
 1/2 g t^2 = 25
t= sqrt(2*25/g)

If original velocity was vh then distance covered 
vh*t=22
taking g=9.8
vh =22/t = 22/sqrt(50/g)=22/2.258=9.73 m/s

question_title: Find the x-intercepts. y= x^2 - 7x + 7? [SEP] question_content: Find the x-intercepts. y= x^2 - 7x + 7

Can someone show me the steps to doing this problem? [SEP] best_answer: x-intercept is where the curve crosses the x-axis

equation of x-axis is y=0
seeking the zeroes of x^2-7x+7
the values of x that make x^2-7x+7 zero.


x^2-7x+7 = 0
x = (7+/- sqrt(7^2-4.1.7))/2
= (7 +/- sqrt(21))/2

so the x-intercepts are
(7+sqrt(21))/2,0) and (7-sqrt(21))/2,0)

question_title: plz help me to solve this question? [SEP] question_content: suppose u have a 100kg tomato having 99% water & 1% solid part. After one day the water is reduced to 98% .Now what is the weight of tomatos. I give the answer 50kg ,plz let me know am i right & if not plz explain the right answer
Thanks in Advance [SEP] best_answer: You are right!!! The 1% solid part remains the same weight (1kg). If the water on the second day is 98%, then the solid must now be 2%. If it is now 2%, it still weighs 1kg, so the water weight is now 49kg. 49 + 1 = 50. 

Another way to look at it is, the solid part is now double the amount it was, but since it didnt grow (did it?), the water must be half what it was.

Lets assume that on day X the water is reduced to 50%. The solid part is now 50%, but still weighs 1kg, so the water must also weigh 1kg, 1kg + 1kg = 2kg.

question_title: how is the possibility that an odd side of a dice will be shown at least 2 times at a 10 times of throwing? [SEP] question_content: and can you describe how to count it? thank you, and beg your sorry if my english was bad, because i'm the personnel of Bad English band, hahaha, just kidding. it's because i'm just a simply stupidman. [SEP] best_answer: Find the probability of the complement occurring and then subtract that from 1.
The complement would be that an odd occurs 0 or 1 times.
P(odd) = .5 and P(even) = .5
P(0 odds) = C(10,0)(.5)^0 (.5)^10 = .0009765625
P(1 odd) = C(10,1) (.5)^1 (.5)^9 = .009765625
.0009765625 + .009765625 = .0107421875
1 - .0107421875 = .9892578125

question_title: why old car use more fuel to run than the new one? [SEP] question_content: what i mean that the old car have to use up more fuel to run than the new buy one. i hope to have a right answer,thank you! [SEP] best_answer: One of the classic inefficiencies of cars of yore is the driveline design.  Take for instance a 1962 V-8 Impala with a hydramatic transmission and rear wheel drive.  The two-speed transmission always allowed slippage between the engine and the wheels, which caused energy loss in the transmission fluid being heated up in the torque converter during all driving situations.  They have cured that in today's automobiles by locking out the torque converter with an automatic clutch.  Putting a 90 degree angle between the input and output is also an energy sucker.  In more efficient front wheel drive cars, the axis of engine revolution is the same as the wheels.  This saves some energy as well. The final drive ratios of cars in the 60's was insane!  A cruising RPM of 3600 at highway speeds was not unheard of--and on a V8!!! Think of the gas going down the tubes.....  Modern cars reduce the final drive ratio and add overdrive to the transmission to reduce cruising speed RPM.  Less RPM means less air consumption and less fuel use.  In the 70's, they caught on and offered rear wheel drive cars with 2.73:1 rear end ratios to save gas.  This hurt acceleration, but was cheaper than offering a 4 speed automatic.  (It eventually happened.)  

A huge determinant of efficiency is COMPRESSION RATIO.  Without computer control and injection, most cars of the 70's (BAD efficiency) had LOW compression ratios, say 8.0.  (And food for thought--the first spark ignition engines had a sorry compression ratio of 4.0:1.  How sad!!  They did not know enough about fuel chemistry at the turn of the century, so that's why the horsepower value of vehicles was so low back in the teens. A four cylinder automotive engine having 10hp in the "old days" with a displacement of 2 liters.  WOW!) New cars have all kinds of tricks to increase compression ratios while running on regular 87 octane fuel.  Current compression ratios include 9.0 to 10.1.  Computers adjust injection and spark ignition timing (to repeat a collegue's information already submitted) along with monitoring piezoelectrick "knock" sensors which make adjustments for preignition "pinging."  In the old carbureted cars, even ones with HEI ignition, there was no way to deal with the pinging. The sure fire way to prevent pinging (and serious damage) is to lower the compression ratio.

Another huge problem with cars of the 70's and 80's were the addition of the catalytic converter and other emission control systems like the huge drain from a "smog pump."  EGR valves put exhaust in the intake charge to reduce nitrous oxides, but that reduces peak combustion temperatures and the available power from the fuel charge.  Running exhaust through the manifold also made the intake charge hotter, reducing efficiency.  Old cars had fixed valve timing, which determines the relationship between power at high rpm and torque at low rpm.  Some manufactures today have adjustment on the exhaust valve timing, and some even adjust both the exhaust and the intake timing to increase efficiency and torque at low RPM while changing valve overlap for high rpm horsepower with a net smaller displacement.

Some modern cars still include EGR, but the catalytic converter technology is much better and more attention to exhaust system design has helped increase MPG.

The actual energy used by the valvetrain has also been reduced by reducing the mass of the components in the valve train.  Using a cog belt to a cam riding right above the valves reduces the energy used to activate the valves.  That can really add up over the life of the engine.  

Another development was the inclusion of the electric cooling fan.  Belt driven fans consumed huge amounts of power from the engine, even if they had a thermal clutch.  Flex fans were supposed to reduce energy, but we are still talkin' in the multi-horsepower range just to move air across the radiator.  The modern c

question_title: for any mathematicians that might be here; what companies actually employ mathematicians? [SEP] question_content: also if u could, give an example of a question a mathematician would work on, and solve the problem. [SEP] best_answer: There are a lot of people who have mathematics degrees that don't have the job title "mathematician". They work as programmers, systems analysts, etc.

One job that does have "mathematician" in it is "actuarial mathematician". They are the people who figure out what your car insurance rates should be based on the likelihood of your being in an accident.

There are also cryptomathematician employed to break codes and cyphers.  The Department of Defense employs a few of those.

question_title: Is it possible to be both a cardiothoracic surgeon and a neurosurgeon at the same time? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: Technically yes.  You could be any combination of specialized surgeon if you really put your mind and soul into it.  After medical school, you are matched to a residency program in the field you would most like to practice in.  Cardiothoracic surgery is about 6 years of residency, and neuro is typically 7.  In either case, the first year or two will be general surgery, and the remainder of your time will be focused on your specialty.  

Commonly, after residency a physician will continue to train and specialize through at least one fellowship of a year or more before attaining a full surgical position with all the bells and whistles.  Completing one residency does not exclude you from being able to train in other areas as well.  

If its what you really want, I believe it is possible to be both.  However, I would caution you that you are looking at 10-12 years of 80 hour work-weeks after med school.  That means you're likely to be 36-40 years old by the time you are done.  Furthermore, the point of specializing is to know everything about a small aspect of medicine.  If you divide your attention between two, its highly unlikely that you would be as well versed at both as you could be at one.  Lastly, money might be an issue as well.  Having two specialties doesn't mean you can do twice as many surgeries.  A hospital isn't likely to pay you twice what you would make with one.  In fact, I would guess that the second specialty would not add a tremdous amount to your paycheck.  Also consider that you will be missing out on roughly $1,500,000 of income while you are going through all the extra training of the second residency.

Like I said if its what you really want....go for it.
I'd say do one, then see how you feel.

question_title: Do aliens exist? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: The short version gives two possible answers; each with corresponding counter-argument:

No - We are Alone.  

-  But the odds that only one intelligent/spacefaring species can evolve throughout the entire known universe, or at least the local galaxy is extremely unlikely, though not impossible.

Yes - Aliens are out there.

- But where are they? And why aren't they here, or at least locally active.  This gets a little more confusing.

Imagine a successful spacefaring civilisation evolves on the opposite side of our galaxy, abou 10000 light-years away.  This race has succesfully colonised it's solar system and is looking at the the stars.  Now without any massive new technologies (no hyperspace or jump-drives, etc) the simplest way to travel between starts is a generation ship (people living and breeding onboard the ship until it reaches its destination and the descendants of the original crew disembark).

Assuming a moderate speed of travel, this races empire will expand at least 0.01% of the speed of light.  That means that this empire will reach Earth in about 100 million years.

This may seem like a long time, but considering that the universe has been around for 15 Billion years, and the Earth itself for 5 Billion years, it is unlikely that no such civilisations have evolved in our galaxy.  

Unless of course, we are alone...

I've probably explained it badly, so probably wise to check out "Fermi Paradox" at Wikipedia.org for another version.

question_title: What makes Physics so hard? What are some good study habits for the subject? [SEP] question_content: I am a college student and will be taking Physics 1 and 2 in the upcoming year. I've heard horror stories about Physics. I've made it through life cramming the night before for tests and doing just fine. I have a feeling this won't work as I get into my harder classes. And I just realized I have no study habits. What is it about Physics that makes it so hard, and any good ways to study for it? [SEP] best_answer: Physics is an extremely visual discipline.  It takes imagining in pictures.  People who think best by getting their hands dirty touching stuff, or (worse still) in words rather than pictures, do more poorly in physics, because most physics teachers think in a visual sense, and most don't have the verbal skills needed to communicate with other types of people.

For most physicists: Newtonian mechanics is billiard balls; Electricity is water flowing around canals and pools and waterfalls and pumps; magnetism is iron filings around a bar magnet; light and sound are light/dark waves in a ripple tank.

Then there's the math.  Now, most physicists don't start with the math, they start with the pictures, and use the math to prop up the answers.

To succeed in physics:  draw lots of pictures - you have to learn to think visually to get it.  Go over solved problems - see how the pictures fit into the math.  Once you realize that there are only about five or six basic equations, and you learn how to solve them (most physicists are bad at math, anyway), you go back to drawing pictures.

And forget about historical personalities.  My god, the way people idolize Newton and Maxwell and Einstein, you'd think they were minor gods.  They were just people, thinking in pictures.

Draw lots of pictures.

question_title: Match the following volumes correctly.? [SEP] question_content: 6. tidal volume (TV) 
7. inspiratory capacity (IC) 
8. functional residual capacity (FRC) 
9. vital capacity (VC) 
10. total lung volume 

a. 6000ml
b. 4800ml
c. 500ml
d. 3600ml
e. 2400ml [SEP] best_answer: Tidal Volume (the amount of air in the lungs without expanding the lungs. ANSWER: D
Inspiratory Capacity: By process of Elimination ANSWER:E
Functional Resudual Capacity the amount of oxygen in your lungs left after breathing out ANSWER C
Vital Capacity: The absolute maximum after breathing in as much as possible ANSWER A
Total Lung Volume: Self Explanatory ANSWER: B

If 1 x 10^A + 2 x 10^B + 3 x 10^c + 4 x 10^D = 24,130 and 
A ≠ B ≠ C ≠ D then what does A/2 + B/4 + C/8 + d/16 equal? [SEP] best_answer: Cool.  Just recall what our place value number system means.

0 is in the 1s col, so it's absent
3 is in the 10s col, so c = 1
1 is in 100s, so a =2
4 is in 1000s, so d =3
2 is in 10,000s so b=4

question_title: How far can one use electrical wires before needing a transformer? [SEP] question_content: My pole that has electricity is 400 feet away, can I plug in to it? Legally of course. [SEP] best_answer: Like everything else, it depends.  The concern is that at the maximum current you will draw, there is sufficient voltage at the point of use.  Voltage drop depends on the amount of current, and the resistance of the circuit.  

You can determine the minimum voltage requirements for whatever you are driving.  Knowing the resistance per foot of various sizes of wire, you could determine the size wire needed.

Now it becomes a matter of economics.  Is larger wire less expensive than a transformer--or two if you are going to maintain the original equipment operating voltage.

question_title: What is mineral oil made from? What minerals are in it? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: Mineral oil or liquid petrolatum is a by-product in the distillation of petroleum to produce gasoline. It is a chemically inert, transparent, colorless oil composed mainly of alkanes and cyclic paraffins, related to white petrolatum. Mineral oil is a substance of relatively low value, and it is produced in very large quantities. Mineral oil is available in light and heavy grades, and can often be found in drug stores

question_title: What could you say about a line if every point on the line has the same x coordinate? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: If every point on the line has the same x coordinate, the line would be vertical. The formula for slope is rise/run. The "run" part would be the change in the x coordinates. Since there is no change, "run"=0. Dividing by zero is undefined, so the line's slope is undefined (not zero). Only vertical lines have an undefined slope.

Also, try plotting points. Choose any x value, and you will see that if every point has that same value, the line will be vertical regardless of the y value.

Also notice and vertical lines are not functions as they do not pass the vertical line test.

question_title: who discovered opals, when was it discovered and how was it discovered? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: It is no wonder why early cultures from around the world have attributed magical properties to the opal. The mysterious patches of color that appear and disappear with every movement give opals a life of their own. Opals have been collected for thousands of years. The oldest opal artifact, estimated to have been collected at around 4000 B.C., was found in a cave in Kenya. Opals were one of the most highly prized gemstones to the Greeks and Romans. Early Greeks believed opals were the source of prophetic powers. As the Roman Empire grew, so did the demand for opals. A Roman Senator, Nonius, chose to be exiled rather than give his valuable opal to Marc Antony who wanted to give it to his lover, Cleopatra. A legend tells of a Roman Emperor who offered to trade one-third of his kingdom for a single opal. The Roman natural historian expressed his difficulty in describing the gem: "... it is made up of the glories of the most precious stones. To describe it is a matter of inexpressive difficulty: There is in it the gentler fire of the ruby, the brilliant purple of the amethyst, the sea-green of the emerald, all shining together in an incredible union." Opals have often found their way into the jewelry and crowns of royalty. Queen Victoria adored opals and kept a fine collection. 

     While opals have always been an object of curiosity and mystery, the powers attributed to it have not always been positive. In the late 18th century, the opal was considered to bring bad luck to its possessor. The Spanish King Alfonso XII had given an opal ring to his wife who died shortly thereafter. The ring was passed on to family members and each person who wore it died mysteriously. Eventually, the king himself wore the ring and he too died unexpectedly. While historians will say that the deaths can be attributed to the cholera epidemic of the times, many have blamed the deaths on the opal.

http://www.gbjewelers.com/education/opals/opal-information.html

question_title: Metabolism of 1 mole of sucrose yields:? [SEP] question_content: how many moles of :

CO2:            
ATP:           
Acetyl CoA:            
pyruvate: 

any sites would be great. thank you in advance. [SEP] best_answer: A sucrose molecule is made up of a glucose and a fructose molecule. 1 mole of sucrose gets broken down to 1 mole of glucose and 1 mole of fructose. The metabolic pathway of both glucose and fructose are very similar. 
1 mole of glucose yields 6 moles of CO2 and 1 mole of fructose yields 6 moles of CO2, therefore, 1 mole of sucrose will yield 12 moles of CO2
1 mole of glucose yields 36 ATP and 1 mole of fructose yields 36 moles of ATP, therefore, 1 mole of sucrose will yield 72 moles of ATP.
Following the same logic, 1 mole of sucrose will yield 6 moles of Acetyl CoA (3 from glucose and 3 from fructose)  and 4 moles of pyruvate (2 from glucose and 2 from sucrose)

question_title: List the 3 types of chemical bonds and explain the diffrences among them? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: Covalent bond: bond in which one or more pairs of electrons are shared by two atoms.

Ionic bond: bond in which one or more electrons from one atom are removed and attached to another atom, resulting in positive and negative ions which attract each other.

Other types of bonds include metallic bonds and hydrogen bonding. The attractive forces between molecules in a liquid can be characterized as van der Waals bonds.

question_title: If we mgnfy a line we see its width(2nd dmnsn) if we cut it into more lines n mgnfy, we see the second dmnsn? [SEP] question_content: I mean to say that if we cut the line (simple) into more parts (linearly) then we see its width(magnified) which refers to its second dimension and quite comfortably the third if we again do the cutting and magnification sequence several times then probably we find that we can still see the 3 dimensions Does it mean that nothing can exist in the 1st and 2nd dimension but compulsorily in the 3rd dimension?or that a single dimension exists in the infinite magnification? [SEP] best_answer: Any line you can make in this physical Universe is 3-dimensional.  A drawing has a 3rd dimension - no surface is ideal, and there has to be something beyond this surface.
If you draw a line, it is also 3-dimensional (otherwise, you would not see it - it would be infinitely thin, and if it is not, it is a rectangle on an uneven surface).

If you ask whether truly 1-D or 2-D objects can exist in our Universe, there is an answer: no and yes.

NO for macroscopic objects: the reason is that there is a minimum unit of space: Planck length. Therefore, you may think of all non-elementary objects in this Universe as being at least 1 Planck length thick in all 3 dimensions.  
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Planck_length

YES for elementary particles. They are viewed either as zero-dimension (points) or one-dimension (strings, with the size of - I think you guessed it - Planck length).
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/String_theory

question_title: how does the nyc water supply work from the source to the sink? [SEP] question_content: Please describe how it works from the source to the sink. [SEP] best_answer: The water comes from a point elevated far above the sink height (a reservoir in upstate NY).

Because its source is higher, the water will flow (downward)--even though the pipes might go 'up' a buiding. Its all about the conservation of energy laws you can learn about in physics.

From the reservoir it is piped to the city, and it gets filtered and treated before it gets to the sink.

The sink valves hold it back until you open them, and let the force of the flow down your drain, where it goes out to the river.

question_title: 7 C(s) +  9 CH4(g)    --> 2 C8H18 (l)  Is it possible? [SEP] question_content: Can we convert carbon to liquid fuel using natural gas?
Is this reaction possible? (Solid+Gas-->Liquiid)
Is it energy eficient?
Has anybody done it?
Are there studies or research papers?
Any usefull links? [SEP] best_answer: It sounds extremely unlikely.  In fact, so unlikely that I would rate it as impossible.  The problem is that the first stage of the reaction would be the splitting of one of the C---H bonds in methane and you would need pretty brutal reaction conditions to achieve this, e.g. temperatures well in excess of 1000°C.  At these temperatures, hydrocarbons such as octane are unstable and simply would not form.  If there is any reaction at all, I would guess that, at fairly high temperatures you would get some acetylene, e.g. by passing a stream of methane over a bed of red-hot carbon :
C(s)   +   CH4(g)   --->   2 C2H2(g)

Note that the equation you wrote is balanced.  But just because you have a balanced equation, that doesn't mean the reaction is feasible.

question_title: Physics problem? [SEP] question_content: Consider a massless cord attached at both ends to hooks in a ceiling. A 20-kg mass is then suspended from the first cord by a second cord. The angles made by the cord with the ceiling are 40 degrees (left angle) and 25 degrees (right angle). Find the tension in each cord.

Please help, ive been trying all day! [SEP] best_answer: The equations you want are:  (i = left, r = right)
Ti*cos 40 = Tr*cos25  and
Ti*sin40 + Tr*sin25 = 20*9.8

Solving this for Ti &Tr will give the tensions in Newtons

question_title: Why exactly do some people need to wear glasses? [SEP] question_content: Just wondering.Is it something to do with the lense in your eye not being able to focus properly or something? [SEP] best_answer: The lens in your eye may be too strong and thus focus the image of the outside world in front of your retina, or it may be to weak and focus the image behind the retina.  By placing a lens (glasses) in front of the eye, we can compensate for this by ensuring the image falls exactly on the retina, which allows for good vision.

question_title: is there a installation system for building windows that withstand high wind forces? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: Consider looking up Polycarbonate

Polycarbonate is a clear polymer that is used in bullet proof glass.  It is commonly used nowadays in homes to resist breaks.  

Acrylic is also used and is more flexible but less impact resistant.

Both of these materials are available at hardware stores such as Lowes.  If you seeking profession installation, just ask about the two materials, acrylic is cheaper then polycarbonate, usually by about 1/3 the cost.  

If you are only considering windows that resist breaking due to wind force, go for acrylic, its cheaper and the wind force, even at high pressure, may bend an acrylic panel, but will not break it.   

The polycarbonate will not only resist winds, it will flex less, and given the right thickness can stop a baseball bat or ball. crow bar, and even thicker, will repel small arms fire.  

Both materials flex to some degree, but return to their original flatness immediately.  Both materials are plastics and must have a UV protective coating to prevent "yellowing"  The protective coating, which is put on the outer surface, should be on any of the material you purchase that is intended for outdoor use.  The coatings guarantee no yellowing for 10 years.

more FYI, The combination of the two materials is used by a particular company to make one-way bullet proof "glass" really  sandwich of the two materials, with the more flexible acrylic on the bad guy's side.

question_title: Radiating  or reflecting light. is what? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: Visible light is the most familiar form of electromagnetic waves.  Light is produced by the rearrangement of electrons in atoms or molecules.

Newton's laws of reflection and refraction treats light as a particle:

Law of Reflection:  When light is reflected from a surface, the angle of incidence EQUALS the angle of reflection.  The angles are measured from the normal (perpendicular) to the surface.

Law of Refraction: Deals with the  way light changes its direction of propagation when it passes from one medium to another.  The light beam transmitted into the second medium is said to be refracted. 

The angle of refraction bends toward the normal if a light beam passes from air into glass (the angle of reflection is less than the angle of incidence).   If the angle of reflection is greater than angle of incidence,  light is bent away from the normal as when it passes from glass to air.

question_title: what would 4(3c + 1) = - (5 - c) be? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: Problem: 4(3c + 1) = -(5-c)

First step is to distribute.
     4(3c) and 4(1) = 12c + 4
     -(5) and -(-c) = -5 + c (negative times a negative is a positive)

Step #2: Write out the new problem.
     12c + 4 = -5 +c

Step#3: Get the variables to one side.
      12c +4 = -5 + c
         -c                   - c
--------------------------------
      11c +4= -5
              -4      -4
----------------------------
       11c = -9

Step#4: Divide:
       11c = -9
      -------   ------
        11       11
         c = -9
               -----
                11

question_title: mechanism of ESR? [SEP] question_content: all about erythrocyte sedementation rate [SEP] best_answer: Here is a simplified explaination of why ESR increases as a result of inflammation. 

The outside of a red cell is positively charged, generally at the same level, except in the middle of the cell (the thinnest part of the biconcave disc) where it is relatively negatively charged. This means that the there is an attraction between this negative charge and the positive charges of other red cells (opposites attract). However, under normal conditions, the positive charges around the rest of the red cell repel the other positive charges of other red cells. This repulsive force is called the Zeta potential. So in the normal state, the Zeta potential is stronger than the attractive force. 
During states of inflammation, there are more immunoglobulins, proteins and acute phase reactants sent out into the blood, these are negatively charged, and reduce the overall Zeta potential, and subsequently the repulsive force. This means that the positive areas on the red cells can now get closer to the negative area of other red cells. And they do so. The nature of the shape of the red cells means that they fit quite neatly (with minimal deformity) into each other, and stack like coins. The more the inflammatory response, the higher the acute phase reactants and other proteins in the blood, and the lower the Zeta potential, the greater the attraction between the red cells, and the higher the ESR.

Hope this helps

question_title: If the world is moving so fast along its axis, around the sun, and through universe, why dont we feel it? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: The world is spinning, so we're like masses attached to a cord and spinning around very fast.  If the cord is cut, then the mass would go bye-bye.

But fortunately our cord, which is gravity, can't be cut, and it holds us to the surface of the earth.  We can't feel it because gravity exerts a force on us much larger than the centrifugal reaction "force", but if it suddenly dissappeared we would feel that force and go flying out of the planet.

About that answer that says that we're moving at the same speed, it's partially right.   I'l put it like this:  We are moving with the earth at its tangential speed, but when we ride on a rollercoaster we are moving at the same speed as the cart, then why can we feel it as it spins and turns?   Things spinning mean acceleration, and acceleration means that we're not on an inertial frame of reference, which is the only place that answer will be valid.

But if you do break it up, yep, it'll burn.  But it's not water then, it's 2 hydrogens and an oxygen.  And when it burns it'll make water.

glasses that are thin enough will not suffer this problem because heat can conduct thru thin materials easily so that thermal expansion is more or less equal on the interior and exterior.

question_title: what do i need to create a control circuit to regulate an AC engine speed? [SEP] question_content: I want to use PWM techniques to regulate the speed of a relativly small AC engine. I know there are integrated circuits that can performe this task, but this is a college proyect so my friends and I need to create the contorl circuits ourselves. First we need to now how PWM technique work (Specifically the mathematical behavior of the wave shape  in time). Now the control circuit will be attached to a three-phase inversor that consits of six IGBT's. The load conected to the inverso will be of course an AC engine. The engine speed will change in time, so we need to control the voltage at the bornes using PWM techniques. Remember we cannot use integrated circuits available on the market other than IGBT's and maybe some operational amplifiers, it is important to build the control circuit ourselves, so the more specific the answers the better. [SEP] best_answer: You should use pulse width modulation (PWM).  PWM is essentially an on-off sequence in time, like a square wave alternating between 0 and 1.

Clearly full voltage will give you maximum speed.  This happens when the voltage is always on.  Now, suppose you only wanted to go half the maximum speed.  You could send a a square wave with 50% duty cycle (on half the time and off half the time) at high enough frequency that the motor will spin at a constant 50% maximum speed.  The motor is like a lowpass filter and therefore, a square wave at high enough frequency will produce a steady response without oscillation.

If you want the motor to go slower, say, at 25% maximum velocity then send a pulse that is on 25% of the time and off 75% of the time.

In reality, if you want 25% speed you may have to send something like a 27% duty cycle because of the time delay between commanding 'on' and the system actually turning 'on'.  In this application, though, I don't think you will have this porblem.

question_title: HOw do electrons create the colors in a line-emission spectrum? [SEP] question_content: please, its very important [SEP] best_answer: A material's emission spectrum is the amount of electromagnetic radiation of each frequency it emits when it is heated (or more generally when it is excited).

When the electrons in the element are excited, they jump to higher energy levels. As the electrons fall back down, and leave the excited state, energy is re-emitted, the wavelength of which refers to the discrete lines of the emission spectrum. Note however that the emission extends over a range of frequencies, an effect called spectral line broadening.

The term often refers to the visible light emission spectrum, although it extends to the whole electromagnetic spectrum, from the low energy radio waves up to high energy gamma rays.

The emission spectrum can be used to determine the composition of a material, since it is different for each element of the periodic table. One example is identifying the composition of stars by analysing the received light.

question_title: who is the founder of Super computer? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: A supercomputer is a computer that leads the world in terms of processing capacity, particularly speed of calculation, at the time of its introduction. (The term "Super Computing" was first used by New York World newspaper in 1929 to refer to a large custom built tabulators IBM had made for Columbia University.)\n\nSupercomputers introduced in the 1960s were designed primarily by Seymour Cray at Control Data Corporation (CDC), and led the market into the 1970s until Cray left to form his own company, Cray Research. He then took over the supercomputer market with his new designs, holding the top spot in supercomputing for 5 years (1985–1990). In the 1980s a large number of smaller competitors entered the market, in a parallel to the creation of the minicomputer market a decade earlier, but many of these disappeared in the mid-1990s "supercomputer market crash". Today, supercomputers are typically one-of-a-kind custom designs produced by "traditional" companies such as IBM and HP, who had purchased many of the 1980s companies to gain their experience, although Cray Inc. still specializes in building supercomputers

question_title: If 3 men can paint a box in 2 days, what part of the job can be completed by 2 men in 1 day? [SEP] question_content: Logic and methodology would be appreciated. [SEP] best_answer: You need to figure out how much of the job a man does in a day.

3 men take 2 days to finish a job.  So 1 man would take 6 days.  Stated another way, a man finishes 1/6 of the job each day.

If you have 2 men, then they would finish 2 * 1/6 = 1/3 of the job in a day.

The answer is 1/3 of the box.

question_title: what is the CE EN1621 standard? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: The CE BACK PROTECTOR standard is labeled EN1621-2. The test is performed with a 5kg “kerbstone” dropped from one meter to create the test impact force of 50 Joules The standard contains two levels of energy transmission performance. 18kN passes LEVEL 1 "basic" compliance and 9kN passes LEVEL 2 "high performance" compliance. So LEVEL 2 protectors allow 50% less energy to reach the spine. .\n\n4kN is the medically recommended level of transmitted force, but is NOT actually required by the current CE back protector standard EN1621-2 LEVEL 1 or LEVEL 2, and most protectors cannot provide this level at the 50 Joule impact level.

question_title: how to subtract using the left-over or add-on method? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: There are many ways. For example to subtract 9 from 14 we add 1 to each number and then subtract. 15-10=5.
Another way is to add numbers to 9 till we get 14.
9+1=10; 10+4=14; and the answer is 1+4=5.
  Another way is to subtract more than the number to be subtracted and add the excess. Subtract 10 instead of 9 from 14 to get 4. Having subtracted 1 
in excess we add 1 to 4 to get 5.

question_title: briefly explain the process of electrophoresis and illustrate it's uses in DNA technology.? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: Electrophoresis is a process used in molecular biology labs where a given protein, often of unknown composition, is migrated through a gel with polarity;positively charged on one side and negatively on another, such that the protein, in this case DNA, is migrated through the gel to create "bands" (visual horizontal lines).  The distance that the DNA fragment migrates is inversely proportional to the (log 10) of their molecular weight.  This enables the researcher to deduct the sequence of the codons within the particular DNA sequence and this is critical in mapping genes and sequencing.

Agarose gel electrophoresis is an easy way to separate DNA fragments by their sizes and visualize them. It is a common diagnostic procedure used in molecular biological labs.
The technique of electrophoresis is based on the fact that DNA is negatively charged at neutral pH due to its phosphate backbone. For this reason, when an electrical potential is placed on the DNA it will move toward the positive pole (source:  http://www-biology.ucsd.edu/classes/bicd101.SP06/Electrophoresis_of_DNA.doc)

See this link for more info:
http://www.vivo.colostate.edu/hbooks/genetics/biotech/gels/agardna.html

question_title: why bananas are first green, then yellow? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: Ripening is a process in fruit that causes them to become more edible. In general, fruits become sweeter, less acidic, less green, and softer as they ripen.

Stages of a plant's life are influenced by hormones. An important plant hormone involved with ripening is the chemical ethylene, a gas created by plants from the amino acid methionine. Ethylene causes increased levels of certain enzymes in fruit, which include:

Amylase, which breaks down starch to produce simple sugars, and Pectinase, which breaks down pectin, a substance that keeps fruit hard. 
Other enzymes break down the lime pigment chlorophyll, which is replaced by blue, yellow, or red pigments.

question_title: For the following probability distribution u= if? [SEP] question_content: Xi  250----300---400
Pi  .30-----.50----.20

a. .50
b. 300
c. 305
d. 317 [SEP] best_answer: I'm assuming u stands for the Greek letter mu.
Mu is used to represent the expectation.  The expectation is found by multiplying each value of x_i by its corresponding probability P_i.  (I'm using the underscore symbol to represent that i is a subscript.)
mu = 250(.30) + 300(.50) + 400(.20)
mu = 75 + 150 + 80
mu = 305, which is choice c.

question_title: What do you think about terraforming? Will it ever be practically possible? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: It seems unnecessary since space settlement will be able to build more than a thousand times the Earth's surface area for us to live on while with Venus you might get the surface area of the Earth after a lot of effort and with Mars you'll get maybe a third or so (unless you do without oceans).

Terraforming though is certainly possible, Mars would be easier than Venus but Venus would probably be a better planet once you finished it.

To terraform Mars you just increase the thickness of the atmosphere, put some plants there to give it oxygen and get some more heat to the planet (either you create a greenhouse effect or you put mirrors in orbit of the planet).  The biggest problem with Mars is the lower gravity.  It might not be a problem or might only be a problem if the Martians want to return to Earth or it might be almost as bad as zero g (and unlike in space it is very hard to make a large centrifuge on a planet).  The higher gravity will also make Mars incapable of holding an atmosphere with a lot of oxygen in it for any great length of time so over millions of years you'll have to replace the oxygen that leaks out.

Venus has higher gravity (about 90% of Earth) so I don't expect gravity to be a problem there although heat is going to be a big problem.  Venus simply receives too much sunlight which is why it is so hot.  Even if you were to remove the atmosphere it would still be 100 °C which is far too hot for anyone to live so you have to reduce the insolation somehow.  Moving the planet would be the best way in my opinion although a giant filter between Venus and the sun (say at Sun-Venus L1) would also work.  Once you reduce the amount of sunlight striking the planet you can start to work on getting the atmosphere down to a more reasonable pressure by removing the CO_2 preferably by putting it into the rocks and then adding water.

With water you can then add plants and get photosynthesis going so that you can get the oxygen atmosphere needed.

Mercury might be another possibility but it combines the problems of Mars (low gravity and small size) with the problems of Venus (too much sunlight).

question_title: Trace the path a drop of blood would take through the cardiac cycle, starting from the left ventricle and e? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: Left ventricle into the aorta via the aortic valve, then through the body, eventually ending up in the vena cava, then the right atrium, through the tricuspid valve into the right ventricle, through the pulmonic valve into the pulmonary artery to the lungs, where it oxygenates, then comes back through the pulmonary vein into the left atrium, through the mitral valve and back to the left ventricle.

[SEP] question_content: Il est simple de voir que ce soir ont a essayer de passer de face alors que les adversaires sont réputé infranchissable, la derniere fois ont ete moins BOURRINS, ont les fesait tourner, enfin l'avant derniere fois, ont a plus de jeux, aucunes stratégies, qu'en pensez vous ? [SEP] best_answer: Il manque à la France un esprit de vrai guerrier sur le terrain. Quand on regarde Dallaglio, ou McCaw (pour ne citer qu'eux), on voit que le rugby est un sport de contact. Les français me paraissent avoir encore peur contre eux. Pourtant, le talent est là (Jauzion, Traille, Rougerie, Swarzeski...), il reste encore à travailler. Le physique est une chose, mais il faut aussi travailler la VITESSE : sur toutes leurs phases de défense, les Blacks sont toujours 4, au minimum, alors que nous ne sommes que deux !! Et quand on voit la vitesse du 8 néo-zélandais, j'ai cru que c'était Rokocoko qui sprintait !! Mais je crois qu'on est plus près qu'eux qu'on ne le croit. Si toutes les pénatouches à 5m sont mises, ça nous fait +21 points, et eux -14pts (deux essais sur deux contres). Ca aurait pu être 24-37. Et encore, le score aurait été mois net, donc les Français auraient toujours pu croire à la victoire (quand il y a -27 après 50 minutes, c'est plus dur que -7 ). Alors, assurons notre jeu, mettons les essais quand on est à 5m, et la suite sera plus facile. Je garde espoir pour le match à Saint-Denis.\n\nALLEZ LES BLEUS

question_title: is corbon's 320gr hard cast 44mag ammo safe to shoot in a model 329pd smith and wesson airlite revolver? [SEP] best_answer: My friend, in my opinion, you have one of the finest .44 magnum revolvers ever made. The 329PD was designed to be the strongest and lightest weight .44 mag. revolver on the planet. With a titanium cylinder and the scandium alloy frame, which by the way has a strength to weight advantage of 70% over steel, it is safe to shoot any weight or  type of round you want. But like any gun, if you give it a continuous diet of hot ammo, it will loosen up sooner or later.\nShooting a .44 mag. 320gr.HC bullet @ 1175fps, you must be doing some serious handgun hunting!\nSo, go ahead and fire away. Have fun and be safe!!!

question_title: Fix old bike or buy new one.? [SEP] question_content: When i bought my trek for $200 i thought it would last a long time but it has gone bad w/ many things wrong w/ it. The estimate to have it fixed would cost $140. So i cant decide whether to fix it or buy a new bike for $140. Someone help, i'm undecided! [SEP] best_answer: There are a lot of things to consider first. How old is the bike? What kind of condition is the frame in? How often and what type of riding do you do?

If the bike is very old you might want to consider getting a new one. Newer bikes have features that you may not have on your bike. For example, more gears, lighter parts, better brakes, etc. Buying a new bike may get you a lot of features that you would not get by having this one fixed. On the other hand, you may not need any of these and your old bike was working just fine until  you started having all these problems.

Check the frame out for wear or damage. If the frame is steal, which I'm guessing it is based on the price you paid, check for rust especially around the spots were the welds are. If the frame is starting to rust, you would just be throwing you money away by adding new parts to a bad frame. If the frame is aluminum and you do any kind of regular riding, consider getting a new bike if this bike is more than 5 years old. Aluminum has a fatigure limit and the frames generally wear out after about 5 years of regular use.

Finally, if you are just a casual rider and use the bike for fun and just getting around on, you may be able to skip some of the repairs they quoted you and just get enough done to keep the bike moving. However, if you ride a lot or ride off road, you will want your bike to be in the best shape possible. $140 is not a lot to pay for a tune up, including adjusting all the deraillers and cables. Drive train parts wear out over time and need to be replaced. If you get a new bike, considering spending a bit more to get a quality bike that will last a long time. $200 is not a lot to pay for a new bike and investing a little more might get you a much better bike. Not only will it last longer but you will have a better experience riding it.

If you are really interested in keeping this bike and don't want to pay the bike shop to fix. Most of the repairs can be done at home with a few simple tools. Get a repair manual from your bike shop and you should be able to fix most anything yourself. Just be careful when taking things apart that you remember how to put them back together.

question_title: Should Mark McGwire make the baseball hall of fame? [SEP] question_content: I say he should.  Steroid use is purely speculative, as he has never admitted it or tested positive for it. [SEP] best_answer: Everyone is bringing up steroids; I don't care if he used them or not - he's NOT a Hall of Famer.

His numbers just aren't there; this is the "Hall of Fame" - not the "Hall of Guys who were fairly good at ONE aspect of a game when there's '5 Tools' behind true greatness."

To me, Big Mac had TWO "HOF" caliber seasons; 1996 and 1998. The guy played 15 years and all he could muster was ONE season over .300 in which he played over 90 games.

.300 is the mark of a 'good' hitter; not even great. Big Mac has a career average of .263; that's average-to-below-average; Big Mac was a BELOW AVERAGE contact-hitter - playing a position that wasn't at a premium defensively - that almost makes him a liability.

583 - his homerun total - is impressive. Very good. Prodigal; even. As is his 10.6 At Bats per Home Run(good for best all time).

But his strikeout totals are pretty 'impressive' too; if you like big numbers. He's 23rd all-time(1596). Which doesn't contrast very nicely with the fact that he isn't in the Top 100 for all-time at-bats - I don't know what he ranks in that; only that it's over 1500 less than the guy who is 100th (Bid McPhee, 8291). What I'm getting at: He strikes out too much to be a hall of famer.

So, he strikes out too much; he doesn't hit for average. He's not even top 5 in home runs - but that's not the worst of it.

He's a choker. He has a .217 career average in the post-season. His prodigal power becomes timid in the post season; 5 HRs in 129 ABs. That's ONE homerun for every 25.8 at-bats; Which is rather pedestrain. So, Big Mac turns into a Kid's Meal under pressure. Hall of Fame? Pshaw - David Eckstein is more of a HOFer once October rolls around. This is a guy they needed to count on; he was a key part of the batting order; called upon to produce - he didn't.

You want to enshrine someone who lived and died(judging by his Batting Average and Strike Outs, mostly died) by the Home Run - an overrated statistic, if you ask me - who can't buy a hit in the post season - into the Hall.

No; just no.

question_title: which are the important tennis tournaments in the world? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: In tennis, a singles player or doubles team is said to have achieved the Grand Slam if they succeed in winning all four of the following championship titles in the same year:

    * Australian Open
    * French Open
    * Wimbledon
    * US Open

These tournaments are therefore also known as the Grand Slam tournaments. They rank as the most important tennis tournaments of the year in the public mind, as well as in terms of world ranking points and prize-money awarded. The titles are known as Grand Slam titles.

question_title: Who knows something about Steaua Bucharest? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: FC Steaua Bucureşti is a Romanian football club based at Ghencea Stadium, Bucharest, Romania. It was founded on June 7, 1947 as ASA Bucureşti (Asociatia Sportivă a Armatei - English The Army Sport Association). The club changed its name several times before settling on Steaua (English: "The Star") in 1961.\n\nBeing the only Romanian football team and the first in Eastern Europe, to win the European Champions Cup in 1986, having also won the European Super Cup in 1987, Steaua is the most successful and the most popular football club in Romania. Alongside the two European trophies, they have also won 23 National Football Championships, 20 Romanian Cups and 5 Romanian Super Cups

I would add a step 0 before his step 1.
With one ball, practice tossing it up with your right hand and catching it in your left hand. Then toss it back from your left hand to your right. You should toss it eye-level high and catch it without looking at your hands.

question_title: How do you set and use a screen in basketball? [SEP] question_content: and what is defensive positioning? [SEP] best_answer: "A screen or a pick in basketball is an offensive tactic to block the path of a defender to free up a teammate for scoring opportunities. A player may use his body to screen but not his arms or legs. He also may not move while setting the screen, otherwise it is called a moving screen and an automatic offensive foul.\n\nA screen can be used to free a teammate with or without the ball. A common tactic of a screen for the ballhandler is the pick and roll."

question_title: what is the difference between figure skating jumps??? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: Almost every budding figure skater I’ve encountered doesn’t want to spend their time learning swivels, crossovers or turns. They want to jump! Who can blame them? Jumping makes you feel like an accomplished figure skater. The first jump learned by every figure skater is the most basic of them all, the waltz jump. Even in its simplicity, this half rotation jump can be a beautiful jump to watch and master and is often used as the cornerstone for mastering the most difficult of jumps, the axel.
In order for a jump to be successful, it has been said the most important aspect is the time spent on the ice two to three seconds before take-off. The waltz jump and axel are the only two jumps where the skater leaves the ice in a forward position. 


A waltz jump begins with a long glide on a right back outside edge (any edge stuff in website?). The right knee should be slightly bent, or soft, and the hips level. The left leg is pointed straight out behind the skating leg allowing the skater to keep their hips level to the ice. The skater then draws their left skate in behind the heel of the skating leg and steps forward onto a left forward outside edge. Leading with the left shoulder, the skater kicks the right leg up and through to begin the lift in the air. Because this is only a half rotation jump, the arms should be held away from the body. If the arms are held tight and close to the body, it will initiate more of a rotation in the air than necessary. In the air, the skater must transfer their weight from the left leg over to the right hip in preparation for landing. As with all jumps, the skater lands on a right back outside edge, knee soft, left leg extended, arms out, and chin high held proudly high.
The good news about the waltz jump is there is not much that can go wrong. If you want to ensure learning the axel is as painless as possible, it’s worth learning and executing the waltz jump correctly. There are several post jump analyses the skater can do to ensure the jump has been executed correctly. First, as with all jumps, spins and edge work, analyze the tracing made by the skating blade. Specific to the waltz jump, the right back outside edge, left forward outside edge and right back outside landing edge should form a continuous arc on the ice, interrupted only by the change in feet from back to front and the distance covered in the jump from take off to landing.

Additionally, the skater knows they are doing the jump correctly when they feel like they are floating suspended in the air, landing squarely and solidly over the right hip. Landing cleanly on a right back outside edge should allow the skater to maintain their speed and provide flow out of the jump.

While gliding on a right back outside edge, the upper body should not be forced around by the edge. If this happens, there will be a tendency to pull your left side back and swing the right leg around the body instead of driving it up and through. Both arms need to drive forward and up, acting as a counter to the forces trying to make you pivot around the left leg.

Great jumpers are not great skaters. Conversely, sound stroking, footwork and spins all aid in a creating a great jumper. Excellent edge quality is essential for jump set ups and landings. Likewise, spinning is vital in achieving perfect vertical air position as well as tight rotations. In jumping, the skater must use their basic skills as a strong foundation for an impeccable jump. Breaking any jump down into small pieces using the skating technique they already possess will allow the skater to learn specific jumps properly and successfully.

question_title: how can i improve...? [SEP] question_content: hi. i was wondering how i could improve on some things concerning hockey. i play for high school jv and am in 8th grade. I need to get faster, alot faster. any suggestions. (i need em really bad) also, how can i improve on stick handeling and shooting? please give detailed and helpful answers. thank you!
   p.s. - for those of you who play good hockey, (like open high school,AAA) how often do you workout practice and what do you eat to stay fit?) [SEP] best_answer: Lots of good suggestions made so far. Skating with weights is a great one..it really helps you feel lighter and quicker. All leg excerises are good, speed starts with your burst and you need leg strength to have burst. 
  To improve stick handling the biggest trick is to get a shorter stick. Most players who struggle with stick handling often have too long a stick. If you cut your stick now with skates on to your nose try cutting it to your chin. If you use a shorter stick it may also help with some speed as it will get you a little lower in your skating position.
  Last there is NO substitute for practice! Listen to the best players around you and the pro's and the common theme you will hear is how hard they work at their game. Dont go through the motions when practicing...keep your focus and practice like it is the end of the game and you need a goal. And practice specific skills during each practice, dont hop around doing a little of this-a little of that.
 Good luck...and remember skate with your head up!

question_title: Is the world baseball classic crap? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: Everyone outside America thinks its a great idea, the rules were a joke, designed by the baseball clubs to hurt the WBC.

It is a great idea to grow the game of baseball internationally, promote it to a new generation outside America, while giving players a chance to represent something they believe in.

The WBC showed some really great games, put new players and countries on the map (Matsuzaka and Korea) 

For one of the more patriotic nations on earth, Americans seem really indifferent towards international sport.

The WBC is not at a high level as of yet, but it will be, as the game grows internationally. 

Baseball has never done as well as its doing now, and its because of the growth internationally of the sport, and the furthering of the talent pool, through international players making up large numbers in the majors.

question_title: Should I trade Josh Beckett for Dontrelle Willis? Look at team and rate too.? [SEP] question_content: My pitchers are:
Beckett, Lowry, Penny, Zito, Zambrano, Wood, Clemens, Lidge, Weathers, Putz, Gagne, and Otsuka. 
I am getting killed in wins (last by far), 1st place by double digits in saves, middle in K and ERA and 2nd to last in WHIP.
I am about 20 innings under the average. 
I am starting Beckett, Lowry, Zito, Zambrano, Lidge, Otsuka, Weathers, and Putz right now (closers everyday and starters on their pitchin day). Eventually Zambrano, Beckett, Wood, Clemens, and Zito will be my starters and Gagne, Lidge and another closer will be getting my innings (Weathers right now but if Otsuka or Putz keep it up they'll stay. Any help/ideas? [SEP] best_answer: I would definitely keep Beckett over Dontrelle, especially if you need wins.

Florida is awful and it won't be better anytime soon, plus Willis is struggling so far, SO it's a no brainer I think.

I would drop Wood and keep Clemens, get a good starting pitcher to replace Wood and you should be fine. A good example of a a pitcher that will get you wins without killing your ERA or WHIP and that is probably laying on the FA list is  Woody Williams.

question_title: Where is the best place to get PADI/Scuba certified in San Francisco? [SEP] question_content: Wife and I looking to take classes in SF and do open water dives on vacation in Carribean, if that's possible, anyone know of good place in SF to get info/take classes? [SEP] best_answer: Great decision!

There are many places to get certified in San Francisco, but I favor Tom Yang at California Dive Center in San Bruno.

Sincere and dedicated, Tom makes diving enjoyable.  He pays attention to his students, and makes sure that you are safe and having a good time.  Very patient.  Tom gets a lot of recommendations, a significant portion of his class is referrals.

When we moved back to the Bay Area, I called three instructors and decided that Tom was the best for us.  My recommendation would be to do the same.  Get at least two more recommmendations and talk to each of them.

Diving is a lot of fun, and your dive instruction is an important part.  There are a lot of instructors, each with his/her unique style.  Having an instructor that you get along with and has a teaching style that you like will be very helpful.  Everyone learns differently, so teaching style and personality of the instructor is important.

Enjoy!
